basics.name: Edison Sun
basics.label: Student
basics.summary: An undergraduate student at Northwestern University, majoring in Mechanical Engineering, Intergrated Science and minoring inComputer Science.

work.name: Cardiovascular MRI Group @ Northwestern Unversity Feinberg School of Medicine
work.summary: Developed and optimized a cross-institutional, two-stage deep-learning workflow for thoracic aorta segmentation in computed tomography angiography scans (CTA), trained on over 380 paired scans from German and U.S. centers—achieving median Dice scores of ~0.95 on same-site data and over 0.93 when combining both datasets, dramatically cutting manual segmentation time. Facilitated an automated preprocessing pipeline that uses lung detection to crop and resample CTA volumes, standardizing inputs for the segmentation model.

work.name: Functional Optical Imaging Laboratory @ Northwestern Unversity, Department of Biomedical Engineering
work.summary: Succeeded advancing diagnostic imaging for glaucoma through developing a robotic system for anterior segment optical coherence tomography (OCT). Created a feature-based montaging algorithm addressing robotic positioning inaccuracies, facilitating precise alignment of multiple OCT scans without reliance on robotic coordinates alone. Improved visualization of ocular aqueous humor outflow pathways essential for glaucoma management.

work.name: Functional Optical Imaging Laboratory @ Northwestern Unversity, Department of Biomedical Engineering
work.summary: Assisted in the development of SpeNet, a spectral classification neural network aimed to improve imaging accuracy in spectroscopic single-molecule localization microscopy (sSMLM) for visualizing low-abundance protein interactions. Drove molecular misidentification down to ≤1.7% (0.5% with score cut-off); a 3 to 1l times improvement over conventional spectral-filtering. Devised an image segmentation model under Dr. Benjamin Brenner, analyzing outer membrane protein distribution using the TOMM20 marker. Produced a supervised learning model to distinguish between adjacent mitochondrial structures in super-resolution images.

awards.title: Northwestern Biomedical Engineering Department Summer Research Award 2025
awards.awarder: Northwestern University, Department of Biomedical Engineering
awards.summary: Awarded a $5400 grant to conduct summer research in the Cardiovascular MRI Group at Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine, focusing on deep learning for thoracic aorta segmentation in computed tomography angiography scans.

awards.title: Junior Science and Humanities Symposium Outstanding Achievement Award 2024
awards.summary: Recognized for outstanding research in the field of robotic optical coherence tomography. Invited to present at the National Junior Science and Humanities Symposium in Chicago, IL.

awards.title: Biomedical Engineering Society High School Poster Competition Honorable Mention, 2023
awards.summary: Received Honorable Mention in the High School Poster Competition at the 2023 Biomedical Engineering Society Annual Meeting for research on robotic optical coherence tomography. Presented findings on a novel robotic system for anterior segment imaging, enhancing glaucoma diagnostics.

publications.name: Freeform robotic optical coherence tomography beyond the optical field-of-view limit
publications.summary: To address challenges in volumetric reconstruction associated with the robotic movement accuracy being two orders of magnitudes worse than OCT imaging resolution, we developed a volumetric registration algorithm based on simultaneous localization and mapping. We imaged the entire aqueous humor outflow pathway, whose imaging has the potential to customize glaucoma surgeries but is typically constrained by the FOV, circumferentially in mice as a test

publications.name: Minimizing Molecular Misidentification in Imaging Low-Abundance Protein Interactions Using Spectroscopic Single-Molecule Localization Microscopy
publications.summary: We characterized the 3-fold reduction of molecular misidentification in the new imaging method using pure samples of different photoswitchable fluorophores and visualized three distinct subcellular proteins in U2-OS cell lines.
